  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/PyExecJS-1.0.2-py2.7.egg/execjs/__init__.py", line 62, in get

items.title: why not support load remote JavaScript like Jquery or other website js
items.body:
just like:
import execjs
xxx  = execjs.load('http://xxx.com/jquery-1.10.2.min.js')

after then we can use  "$("#id")" easily to select element with jquery syntax

items.title: unexpected token, a hard javascript to eval, how to solve this, thanks
json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)
Upgrade/unpin six
items.body:
[Six](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/six) released a new version (`1.11.0`). PyExecJS's version is pinned to the previous version (`1.10.0`). Is there a reason why it is pinned to this exact version?

As a result this package is incompatible with any package that requires a six version greater than `1.10.0`.

Would it be possible to change the pin to something more forgiving, like `six>=1.10.0`?

python2.7，win7

items.title: ProgramError: <exception str() failed> in cooperation with coffeescript
items.body:
Hi,

I wanted to use the coffeescript package, which uses this one in order to execute the coffeescript code, for compilation matters against my working coffee script files. They compile fine using the coffee tool via command line. But using coffeescript.compile() on them results in the following.

>>> c2=coffeescript.compile(c)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\coffeescript\__init__.py", line 104, in compile
    return _default_compiler().compile(script, bare=bare)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\coffeescript\__init__.py", line 81, in compile
    "CoffeeScript.compile", script, {'bare': bare})
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\execjs\_abstract_runtime_context.py", line 37, in call
    return self._call(name, *args)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\execjs\_external_runtime.py", line 87, in _call
    return self._eval("{identifier}.apply(this, {args})".format(identifier=identifier, args=args))
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\execjs\_external_runtime.py", line 73, in _eval
    return self.exec_(code)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\execjs\_abstract_runtime_context.py", line 18, in exec_
    return self._exec_(source)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\execjs\_external_runtime.py", line 83, in _exec_
    return self._extract_result(output)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\execjs\_external_runtime.py", line 165, in _extract_result
    raise exceptions.ProgramError(value)
execjs._exceptions.ProgramError: <exception str() failed>

I'm using Python 2.7.12 under Windows 10 Anniversary 64-bit. Since the problem occurs inside PyExecJS I thought it would match best here.

Any idea where this comes from? If yes, any possibility to make these error messages kind of more informative? This doesn't tell me anything...

Best Regards.

Toni

items.title: How do I capture console.log output?
items.body: Is it possible to capture the output of a process?

items.title: How do I include pyexecjs in a secure way?
items.body:
I'm new to pyexecjs and want to use it to allow small user scripts.

Right now I can use all the things my node environment offers me, i.e.

```
import execjs
ctx = execjs.compile("const fs = require('fs'); const insecure = () => fs.readdirSync('.');");
ctx.call("insecure")
```

Is there a way to "sandbox" the node environment and only allow certain things?

Thank you for this project, it has been a pleasure to use so far :)

Send messages back to python.

Is it possible to receive messages from the js script like python-shell can https://github.com/extrabacon/python-shell?
It would be very helpful for debugging.

items.body:
I have Python 2.7, PyExecJS-1.3.1, PhantomJS 2.1.1.

```
>>> import execjs
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/.../PyExecJS-1.3.1-py2.7.egg/execjs/__init__.py", line 26, in <module>
```

items.title: Node should be added to the requirements and note that it is the only runtime that works for Windows 7.
items.body:
Windows 7 64-bit
pyexecjs 1.1.0
pyv8 1.0
NodeJS 4.0.0

Using execjs with pyv8 (it seems that PyV8 takes precedence):

``` Python
import execjs

execjs.get().name
Out[2]: u'PyV8'

from react import jsx
jsx.transform('helloworld.jsx')
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<ipython-input-4-ba80c49e788e>", line 1, in <module>
    jsx.transform('helloworld.jsx')

  File "C:\Python27\python-2.7.6.amd64\lib\site-packages\react\jsx.py", line 64, in transform
    return JSXTransformer().transform(jsx_path, **opts)

  File "C:\Python27\python-2.7.6.amd64\lib\site-packages\react\jsx.py", line 51, in transform
    js = self.transform_string(i.read(), **kwargs)

  File "C:\Python27\python-2.7.6.amd64\lib\site-packages\react\jsx.py", line 45, in transform_string
    raise TransformError(e.message[7:])

TransformError: ()
```

'JScript' was my original runtime:

``` Python
import os
os.environ['EXECJS_RUNTIME'] = 'JScript'
jsx.transform('helloworld.jsx')
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<ipython-input-7-ba80c49e788e>", line 1, in <module>
    jsx.transform(helloworld.jsx')

  File "C:\Python27\python-2.7.6.amd64\lib\site-packages\react\jsx.py", line 64, in transform
    return JSXTransformer().transform(jsx_path, **opts)

  File "C:\Python27\python-2.7.6.amd64\lib\site-packages\react\jsx.py", line 51, in transform
    js = self.transform_string(i.read(), **kwargs)

  File "C:\Python27\python-2.7.6.amd64\lib\site-packages\react\jsx.py", line 45, in transform_string
    raise TransformError(e.message[7:])

TransformError: or: 'undefined' is null or not an object
```

But installing NodeJS and using it as the runtime works:

``` Python
os.environ['EXECJS_RUNTIME'] = 'Node'

In [9]: jsx.transform('helloworld.jsx')
Out[9]: u'var HelloMessage = React.createClass({displayName: \'HelloMessage\',\n  render: function() {\n    return React.createElement("div", null, "Hello ", this.props.name);\n  }\n});\n\nReact.render(React.createElement(HelloMessage, {name: "John"}), mountNode);'
```

So I guess that should be added to the readme. I have uninstalled PyV8 and now Node is the default runtime under execjs.

items.title: PyExecJS and Web Sockets
items.body:
Hi,

Is it possible to use PyExecJS to load some JS that initiates a Web Socket connection and then asynchronously calls back from JS to Python? 

As per another question about async JavaScript I assume it's not possible today. Do you confirm?

Thanks.

items.title: Support for custom JSON encoder
items.body: Use case is dict contains bson ObjectIDs which need to be serialized to strings.  I have a PR for this as well, will submit all of them next week once everything is approved.

items.title: Support runtime with raw result.
items.body: Use case is phantomjs renders a page as PDF to stdout, I don't want that output to be passed through the decoding and extract result process.  I have a PR for this if it's wanted.

items.title: Make it possible to `require` external libraries.
items.body:
Currently, one can not `require` external libraries in JS script.

Example: https://gist.github.com/brandonwoo/823856a82145c9c76f8b

One of solution is adding parameter of directory to `execjs.exec_` and other methods.
However, the solution depends spec of `nodejs`.

Where should be specify working directory? (or not specify working directory).

items.title: Plans to support asynchronous javascript?
items.body:
Any plans to add support for asynchronous javascript? There's a Ruby project, [ExecJS Async](https://github.com/ericallam/execjs-async), that does this with Node.js:

"ExecJS lets you run JavaScript code from Ruby. ExecJS Async allows you to execute, and receive results from, asynchronous javascript."

Thanks!

items.title: Upgrade to 1.0.5 breaks PyReact + nodejs JSXTransformer
items.body:
I am using django 1.6.5, django-pipeline 1.3.26, and PyReact 0.4.1, and upgrading from PyExecJS 1.0.4 to 1.0.5 breaks the pipeline jsx compilation with the cryptic message `ce Error: JSXTransformer is not defined`.
Looking deeper, I ran the commands that were actually being called behind the scenes, eg `/usr/bin/nodejs /tmp/execjsJ9PCNo.js` and found the actual output was `["err","ReferenceError: JSXTransformer is not defined"]`

Downgrading to 1.0.4 I tried compiling the same file again, and diffed the results.  The only difference was in the first line, where 1.0.5 produced:

```
(function(program, execJS) { execJS(program) })(function(module, exports, require) { /**
 * JSXTransformer v0.11.2
 */
...
```

and 1.0.4 produced:

```
(function(program, execJS) { execJS(program) })(function() { /**
 * JSXTransformer v0.11.2
 */
...
```

The output from trying to run these files with node was as follows (files renamed for clarity):

```
$ nodejs PyReact-0.4.1_PyExecJS-1.0.4.js

["ok",{"code":"/** @jsx React.DOM */\n'use strict';\n\nvar Test = React.createClass({displayName: 'Test',\n  render: function () {\n    return (\n      React.DOM.span(null, \"Hello\")\n    );\n  }\n});\n","extra":{},"sourceMap":{"version":3,"file":"transformed.js","sources":["source.js"],"names":[],"mappings":"AAAA,qBAAqB;AACrB,YAAY,CAAC;;AAEb,IAAI,0BAA0B,oBAAA;EAC5B,MAAM,EAAE,YAAY;IAClB;MACE,cAAK,CAAA,IAAC,EAAA,OAAY,CAAA;MAClB;GACH;CACF,CAAC,CAAC"},"sourceMapFilename":"source.js"}]

$ nodejs PyReact-0.4.1_PyExecJS-1.0.5.js
["err","ReferenceError: JSXTransformer is not defined"]

$ 
```

items.title: Invalid syntax error using easy_install
items.body:
Python 2.7 has support for set comprehensions, which I believe is breaking Python 2.6 support for PyExecJS.

:~# easy_install PyExecJS
/usr/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/setuptools/package_index.py:156: UserWarning: Unbuilt egg for setuptools [unknown version](/usr/lib/python2.6/dist-packages)
  Environment.**init**(self,_args,_*kw)

Best match: PyExecJS 1.0.1
Downloading http://pypi.python.org/packages/source/P/PyExecJS/PyExecJS-1.0.1.zip#md5=9d7b4d6d5b3a43bd76f3754d7031a71c
Processing PyExecJS-1.0.1.zip
Running PyExecJS-1.0.1/setup.py -q bdist_egg --dist-dir /tmp/easy_install-iet2Gt/PyExecJS-1.0.1/egg-dist-tmp-028w8Y
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
  File "setup.py", line 11, in <module>
  File "/tmp/easy_install-iet2Gt/PyExecJS-1.0.1/execjs/**init**.py", line 78
    return {name:runtime for name, runtime in _runtimes.items() if runtime.is_available()}
                           ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
